Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 760053d8a9a840ce92628f50275daae8eed51a6f
Since you're in this repo you probably don't need this prefix.
Removed prefix
With how different this functionality is, it probably implies there should have been two different commits.  Can see what others think.
Acknowledged
Since pretty much all of your traces have useful metadata, it would be great if you could switch to lg2 so that the data showed up in the trace, instead of just in the metadata.
Converted all log to lg2
since this class doesn't own any data, it could probably just be a free standing function.  We can wait and see what others think.

Yes, I agree this is confusing.  The file name doesn't match the class name, and the class is really just a function.

I'd suggest changing this to a function.  It could probably just be in main.cpp right?
Added this function to main.cpp

This sentence is hard for me to understand.  It is pretty long.  Maybe split it into three like the following (not sure if this is what you are saying):

Updated ItemUpdater::scanDirectory to search for the installed PSU model directory.  For example, the PSU model 2B1E should have a
directory named /usr/share/obmc/psu/2B1E.  The firmware file and the MANIFEST reside in this model directory.
Modified sentence
Nit: within
Fixed
Looks like you removed a blank line between methods.  I think you should put that back.  I'm surprised clang-format didn't complain about it.
Added empty line
There is an unwanted space here right?
Removed space

I think you can make this match permanent, probably part of the ItemUpdater class.  And then when it fires, send it down basically the same path as onPsuInventoryChanged, which is made to update PSUs when an existing Present property changes to true (meaning PS was removed and then replaced).  That way, you can handle someone adding a power supply to a previously empty slot say 10 minutes in the future.  And then, it will also handle the genesis case where they come in after startup due to how EM works.


With those changes in place, I think there may still may a window where PIM starts and restores what was previously on D-Bus, but if a PS was removed when AC was off, or replaced with one of a new model, then the code won't get the right value from d-bus as psu-monitor may not have run yet....
Acknowledged
object_path is a struct with a str std::string member, so when you need the string you can just do path.str.
Done
Since the path of the newly added PSU is known from the signal, you wouldn't need to call this function anymore.
Done
as I mentioned above, this function would just process 1 PSU.
Done
Nit: 'to extract' is here twice
Done

Is this grabbing the present psu's model/ccin from inventory-manager?  In general we need to change it to get the ccin from sysfs instead, as PIM will cache the psu info. If a psu is replaced with a psu with a different ccin when AC is removed from the system, we can't use the cached (old) value from PIM, we should get the actual ccin from sysfs, that way we are guaranteed to get the correct ccin directly from the psu.

I'm not sure if it is also needed in item_updater.cpp onPsuInventoryChanged(), and/or in activation.cpp isCompatible().
Acknowledged
nit: probably don't want to delete blank lines between functions...
Done

I'm not sure the changes here are correct.

The original method loops through all of the sub-directories, handling their manifest files and creating other objects for PSU code update.

The modified version only looks for one sub-directory.  This implies it only supports one PSU model?  Not sure if that is a reduction of function over the current code.  Since the current code stores a PSU model in each PSU struct, it seems like maybe it supports multiple models?

What was the reason for changing the current code?  I assume something was not working?

Yes, the original code loops through all sub-dirs. The implementation doesn't work for multiple PSUs model. Looping through dirs and collect all versions from each manifest file is wrong.
Original code line 446 compare dir and model must match, so if the PSU model is 2B1E only 1 dir can be 2B1E.
typo
Done
typo
Done

It is confusing that there is also a psuMatches data member with a vector of match_t objects.  Could this match just be put in the same vector?  Otherwise maybe this variable name should have something added to explain the difference?
Renamed psuMatch to psuMatchInterface
nit: unintentional delete of blank lines 10 and 14?
Done
Nit: Shouldn't remove blank lines between functions.
Done
Nit: Blank line inadvertently removed?
Done
This worries me a bit.  The previous implementation was creating D-Bus objects that probably need to be there?
Code changed not needed
Temporary debug should be removed?
Done
As noted above, it seems like some D-Bus activity that is probably supposed to be happening is not anymore?
Changed function and this is correct
Is there a reason to change this?  The previous code would return the service every time.  If this is needed, the old code that is commented out should be removed?
Done

If the loop above does not find a model, path and manifest will be set to dir (the root directory above the model directory).  This is confusing since line 447 and 454 will return true, but it is not checking what you want.

It would probably be better to set path and manifest to an empty path at the top of this method.  Then after the loop above exit if they are still empty.

If the loop above does not change the path and manifest,then will change to log an error "Model directory not found".
If the PSU model is 2B1A and there is a file in /usr/share/obmc/psu/2B1A then an error logged "The path is not a directory"

I know you're doing this because the Asset interfaces comes in after the PSU one, but it still makes me nervous.

Since it would be tricky to add an interfacesAdded watch on the Asset interface for the PSU since you'd don't know its object path until you get it from this signal and it isn't a unique interface, I don't think we can go that route.

What do you think Shawn?

I agree this is risky and might not work when the BMC is slow, such as during a BMC reset while the host is running.  In general we have run into problems with hard-coded timeouts.  That is why we use listeners instead.

processPSUImage() currently adds PropertiesChanged listeners for the PSU object paths so it can detect changes in the present and model properties.

One approach would be to make processPSUImage smarter so that it tries to get model/present.  If not found (because not ready yet), it adds interfacesAdded listeners for the PSU object path?  If found, it stores them.  Either way it also adds PropertiesChanged listeners.  That is necessary to support hot plug.
Removed getService call, added 5s timer in while loop to retrieve present state and model.
up above in processPSUImage() the code uses the same service for the Item and Asset interfaces, and I think that's OK to do here too.
Done

This method assumes it is called only once when the app begins.  When called from here, it is going to create duplicate objects for any PSUs that were previously found.

I agree with calling it here, as it has a bunch of logic you don't want to copy/paste.  It has the logic to get present and model and store them, so I don't think you need to duplicate that here.  You can probably just call the three methods below if you find the PSU interface.  However, those methods need to be updated to work when called a 2nd or 3rd time.
Used flag to indicate when the psu object created.
how about psuInterfaceMatch.
Done

It seems like the methods are listed first within the private section, and then the data members follow.  So this new method should probably be added after invokeActivation().

Also, this class is already listening for interfacesAdded for version objects.  So maybe this should be onPSUInterfaceAdded() or something?
Renamed to onPSUInterfaceAdded and moved to after invokeActivation

Reading the commit history on this file, this service file checked into the repo is just an example one, and the real one is then installed from the bitbake layer which would override this one:

"Add an example psu-update@.service that shows how the arguments are
passed to systemd unit and expanded to command line arguments."
Hmm, I will investigate how this will work from bitbake, without this change it will call for update.
Service will have another push to meta-ibm.
FWIW, this would get called for all 3 of the interfaces you are interested in - item.psu. asset, and inventory.item
Modified to path instead of path_namespace.
did you hit a 1 byte version?

No, I did get compare by the current level only when no manifest file exist for example if the psu current level 003000390030 and there is no manifest file phosphor-psu-code-manager invokes `psutil --raw --compare 003000390030`

Here is an example of the call when there is a manifest file version=030303030303
`psutil --raw --compare 003000390030 030303030303`
but why do you care about the versions.size() < 2?
This is string of versions which will be sent to psutil, if the current version only sent the reply will be same version and there is no dir or no fw in /usr/share/obmc/psu will cause an assert.
Versions is a map of version object (string and value). To compare we need at least 2 strings.
Compare will require minimum of 2 strings version to compare.
instead of adding the objectCreated member, can you just look for the object path in psuPathActivationMap?
Removed objectCreated and used psuPathActivationMap

Aren't lines 407 and 411 going to create duplicate match objects/callbacks when this method is called multiple times.  I think it was previously only called once from the constructor, but now it can get called additional times from onPSUInterfaceAdded().
Yes, they should be part included in the condition above
Can just remove this comment
Remove commented out code
Done
Done
this while loop probably needs some comments on why retries are necessary

I don't quite understand this loop.  EntityManager puts all the possible PSUs on D-Bus.  I assume the PSU app will create a PSU path for each one; some may be present and some may be missing.

The code update app gets an InterfacesAdded event for a PSU path that is added by the PSU app to InventoryManager.

If that PSU has a present property, and the property is set to false, then this will keep looping for 10 seconds?

Also, since no exception is being thrown in that case, this is in a *tight* loop with no sleeps.

Should it be looping until it gets the present property, rather than looping until the present property is true?
Changed to break out of the loop when present property retrieved or timeout
Added comments
if this path is expected, I don't think we'd want to see an error trace.
Modified error to INFO

Should it break out of the while loop here?  Not sure why you'd want to keep looping since you found the property.

Also, we have the same general issue as the previous loop.  The model property could be "" if the PSU app was unable to obtain the model.  For example, maybe the driver couldn't get it, or there is an off-the-shelf PSU that doesn't provide that data.  If the model property exists but is set to "", this is going to keep looping.  And since it won't throw an exception, it will be in a tight loop since no sleep will occur.
Modified after reading the property to break out. I the  model is "" then there is no firmware location. The model is the trail of the firmware path.
same comment as above
Added comment
Nit: images
Done

Can't you just change line 164 to be `if (versions.size() < 1)`.  Seems weird to build a string, and then parse the same string.

Also, if versions.size() == 1, should it just return that one version instead of ""?  One likely scenario is there one image file in the file system, and all the PSUs are at that version.  So that latest version is that one version right?  We can just return it and not call the command line tool?
In previous version I tried versions.size I was getting wrong number of version later found out HW issue. Restoring to original code
instead of a new loop, can you just add this to the loop starting on line 169?
I don't need to count number of args, restore to original code.
did you run into a case where it had one, or are you just protecting from a bad case?
Yes, I did see compare with one version. This happened on particular system due to HW issue. I will restore to original code.
I think this is not true now right?  It polls until it gets the present property or the timeout is reached.
Done
Looks good to me
Unnecessary changes
Shawn made comment to restore blank line.
Nit: Add blank line
Done
